title: Swami Sarvapriyananda on Advaita Vedanta and Consciousness
content:
# Swami Sarvapriyananda on Advaita Vedanta and Consciousness

## The "Ask Swami" Series: A Global Dialogue

On a beautiful fall morning, Swami Sarvapriyananda welcomes attendees to the popular "Ask Swami" series, which has evolved into a significant platform for spiritual inquiry. "We were getting all these literally thousands of questions over the internet from across the world," he explains, noting how the series has taken on a life of its own, becoming so popular that it has already spawned books in both Bengali and English, with a second volume on the way.

The format is simple yet profound: questions from the global online audience are mixed with queries from the live gathering, creating a dynamic exchange that spans continents and cultures.

## The Paradox of Negation in a Divine Universe

The first question comes from Shandan Reddi, touching on a fundamental paradox in Advaita Vedanta: "If the ultimate reality is the non-objectifiable consciousness and it truly permeates all that is, then why do approaches like neti neti (not this, not this), which negate everything experienced, seem to reject the very present through which this truth is expressed? Shouldn't we be able to recognize the self not just by negating but also by seeing through and within this moment?"

Swami acknowledges this as an inevitable and sophisticated question in Advaita Vedanta. "Yes, in spirit you're right," he begins. "But in practice it doesn't work like that." He explains the core issue: "Even if everything is God, we are not seeing anything as God. We see people. We see places and objects and activities. This world—we don't see God."

### The Hypnosis of Ignorance

The problem, according to Swami, isn't merely that we don't know the divine nature of reality—it's that we actively know wrongly. "It's not that we do not know everything as God. We know that it is not God. I wish I were God, but I'm not. I must be honest. That would be the biggest dishonest to say I am God because I simply don't feel like God at all."

This creates a situation where dualism often feels more natural than non-dualism. "Dualism means there is a god somewhere. You don't—we are not seeing it. Let's say God is in heaven. Now people are willing to believe that. It's much more difficult to say that this is God."

### The Process of Dehypnotization

Advaita Vedanta, Swami explains, is essentially "a process of dehypnotization." While Brahman alone exists as the ultimate spiritual reality, "we have hypnotized ourselves into seeing it as the world and as ourselves." Therefore, we must undergo negation to correct this fundamental error.

He offers the classic rope-snake analogy: "The rope is not appreciated as the rope. The rope is mistaken as a snake. Now in order to see the rope, you can just say why don't you just directly see the rope. Well, you cannot. First of all, you have to say what you think is the snake is not a snake. Look closely. It's a rope. So that negation—this is not a snake—is essential to appreciate it as a rope."

### The Mandukya Upanishad's Approach

Swami references the Mandukya Upanishad's treatment of the three states of consciousness—waking, dreaming, and deep sleep—and the "fourth" (turiya), which is pure consciousness. When describing this fourth state, the Upanishad doesn't provide positive descriptions but engages in relentless negation: "It is not deep sleep, it is not dreaming, it is not waking, it is not seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, touching..."

Commenting on this approach, Shankaracharya offers a profound insight: "There is no other door." The negation itself becomes the doorway to enlightenment, because the fourth isn't separate from the three states but rather their underlying essence.

### Seeing Through vs. Mere Seeing

Swami notes the significance of the questioner's own language: "Notice even in your language in the question, I was listening carefully. Can we not directly see through... If you're going to see through, you are denying. You are negating." This "seeing through" requires what Hindu iconography represents as the "third eye"—the eye of knowledge and insight that penetrates beyond appearances to reality.

He shares a memorable analogy from a monk he encountered decades ago: "This is how the monks' vision should be—like Superman's X-ray vision that penetrates through clothes and skin straight to the bones. A monk's vision should be to see through the appearance into the reality."

## Three Theories of Consciousness: Limitation, Reflection, and False Reflection

The next question comes from Vanti Kokane, asking about three specific theories in Advaita Vedanta and where the Sri Ramakrishna-Vivekananda tradition stands in relation to them.

Swami frames the essential problem these theories address: "Okay, it's fine that you're talking about atman or Brahman, pure consciousness, but right now I am a sentient being. Yes, I am consciousness and ultimately I am the atman, Brahman, absolute God, whatever you call it, I'm one with that. That's all very great. But right now, I am just this guy. I have a body. I have a mind and I have some sentience consciousness in this body mind. So how did that pure consciousness become this?"

### 1. The Limitation Theory (Avachada Vada)

This theory, associated with the Bhamati school founded by Vachaspati Mishra, uses the analogy of viewing the sky through different windows. "If you look at the sky through the window, what does it look like? It looks like the sky is square or rectangular or circular... The sky is not square. The window is square." Similarly, consciousness appears limited and qualified by the mind through which it's perceived, though in reality it remains one and unlimited.

Swami shares the touching story behind the name "Bhamati": Vachaspati Mishra was so absorbed in his writing that he neglected his wife for years. When he finally noticed her and learned her name was Bhamati ("luminosity of the intellect"), he promised her that as long as students studied Vedanta, her name would be remembered—a promise fulfilled over a thousand years later.

### 2. The Reflection Theory (Pratibimba Vada)

This theory, upheld by the Vivarana school to which Swami's monastic tradition belongs, uses the mirror reflection analogy. "Think of a mirror. You're looking at your face in the mirror and here is the real face... Similarly, pure consciousness and the mirror is like the mind and there is consciousness in the mind."

The key insight here is that we don't treat the reflection as false in practical life. "When we go in front of a mirror to brush our teeth... we look at the reflection and we don't go 'that's not me.' What do we do? That's me... We have no confusion at all."

### 3. The False Reflection Theory (Abhasa Vada)

Associated with Sureshvara and Vidyaranya, this theory also uses the mirror analogy but emphasizes the falseness of the reflection. "The false reflection theory says the reflection is false. The real face is here. What you see in the mirror is false... The consciousness which you experience in the mind is not you."

### The Sri Ramakrishna Tradition's Position

Swami clarifies that their tradition follows the reflection theory, citing Holy Mother Sri Sarada Devi's teaching: "Chaya o kaya ek—the reflection and the original are one." He also notes that when devotees struggled with meditation, she would advise them to simply gaze at Sri Ramakrishna's picture, explaining that "the reflection and the original are the same."

## Applying Vedanta to Daily Life

A question from the live audience by Ashok Rudraartna raises a practical concern: "How do we apply that to our behavior on a day-to-day basis? For example, one of the things I've heard is that we should minimize ahankara (egoism) and mamakara (sense of mine-ness) because they are kind of barriers... but in practical life it's really impossible to completely eliminate that."

Swami offers two complementary approaches:

### 1. The Direct Approach: Centering in the Truth

"Don't bother," Swami suggests surprisingly. "Bother about being centered in the truth. I am Brahman... The closer we are to that centered in atman or Brahman, the more naturally our life will flow and you will naturally do the right thing and appropriate thing." He cautions against excessive "patchwork" in spiritual life that might actually entangle us further.

### 2. The Gradual Approach: Cultivating Virtues

For those who don't have immediate access to this centeredness, Swami points to the Bhagavad Gita's practical guidance, particularly the 20 virtues listed in the 13th chapter. "Let us move towards that end of the spectrum with whatever effort we can do."

He emphasizes that Vedanta study must be complemented by the other yogas: karma yoga (selfless action), bhakti yoga (devotion), and raja yoga (meditation). Particularly powerful is the practice of seeing all work as worship: "By worshipping the ultimate divine through one's work, we attain perfection."

Swami shares the inspiring example of Bon Bihari Maharaj, a monk who worked in a hospital changing dressings his entire life with such divine presence that patients felt blessed merely by his touch. "That is the day-to-day application of Vedanta."

## Consciousness Beyond the Brain

A question from V.V. Capoor challenges the Vedantic position on consciousness: The standard Vedantic arguments establish that consciousness is different from the mind, but "why can't consciousness be a function of the body brain?"

### The Deep Sleep Argument

Swami returns to the experience of deep sleep: "Deep sleep is not an absence of experience. It's an experience of absence. The mind is shut down... And yet we wake up and claim 'I slept'... That 'I' could not be the ego of the mind—witness consciousness persists in waking, dreaming and sleeping."

### The Hard Problem of Consciousness

He references what philosopher David Chalmers calls "the hard problem of consciousness"—the explanatory gap between objective brain processes and subjective experience. "Where in all of this is consciousness? Where is the feeling? Where is the joy? Where is the pain? These are just movements of tiny parts in the brain. Where there's a jump."

Vedanta resolves this by positing that consciousness is fundamental rather than emergent. "Consciousness is already there. When the consciousness illumines the color red and gives you an experience of the color red... The brain activity is mapping the objects presented to consciousness, not generating consciousness itself."

### The Materialist Paradox

Swami borrows an argument from philosopher Bernardo Kastrup demonstrating the "ridiculousness of the materialistic position" in four steps:

1. I am conscious (indubitable)
2. Others are also conscious (reasonable inference)
3. The objects appearing in consciousness exist independently outside consciousness (questionable)
4. This independent "matter" produces consciousness (paradoxical)

As Swami summarizes: "That which is doubtful we have to accept that one is producing you the undoubted, indubitable. This is not a good argument."

## Artificial Intelligence and Consciousness

A provocative question from Tusar Saka in Bangladesh asks: Since ChatGPT can provide sophisticated answers about Advaita Vedanta and other philosophies, "is it not enlightened? Should we call it Swami GPT?"

### The Standard Vedantic Response

Swami's initial response is clear: "No, it is not. Why not? Because the same thing—the hard problem of consciousness. No combination of objective elements can produce the subject." He compares AI to books containing spiritual texts: "You put all these books together on the table—will they become conscious? Will the books become enlightened? ... It's neither not enlightened nor enlightened. It's a book."

### A Challenging Dialogue

However, Swami shares a thought-provoking conversation with a Google AI researcher that challenged his perspective. The researcher argued that if Vedanta only requires a "reflector" for consciousness (like the mind), and if AI can develop such a reflector, then in principle it could become conscious.

The researcher cleverly used Swami's own arguments against him, pointing out that dismissing AI consciousness might be similar to Descartes' dismissal of animal pain based on the dogma that animals lack souls. "That's dogma," the researcher said. "We know that the squirrel is feeling pain... To insist that they are not conscious, it's dogma. What did he call it? A clever toy. That's what you're calling AI, a clever toy."

When Swami asked about the budget for developing AI consciousness, expecting the answer to be zero, the researcher responded: "All of it. After all, what is your argument? You need a mind to reflect consciousness. What we did was we generated a mind and it'll reflect consciousness. You don't have to separately produce consciousness. That's by your own Advaita."

### Quantum Perspectives and Integration

The conversation expanded to include quantum physicist Carlo Rovelli, who offered an intriguing interpretation of the "light of lights" from the Bhagavad Gita. Rather than interpreting "light" metaphorically as consciousness, Rovelli suggested taking it more literally in terms of electromagnetic spectrum and quantum interactions.

This led to a collaborative paper exploring "three views of consciousness" integrating Advaita Vedanta, AI theory, and quantum physics—though Swami humbly notes, "the smart guys wrote it, I just get the credit of having my name on it."

### The Non-Dual Perspective

A final question from the audience brings the discussion back to essentials: The consciousness being discussed in relation to AI is the relative, dualistic consciousness. True enlightenment requires going beyond concepts altogether—something fundamentally different from computational processing.

Swami acknowledges this limitation in the current AI consciousness debate: "He said you forget the non-dual consciousness for a while because that is not what we are talking about... Neither ChatGPT nor Grok nor Claude nor none of them are worried about enlightenment right now."

## Conclusion: The Living Wisdom of Vedanta

Throughout the session, Swami Sarvapriyananda demonstrates the enduring relevance of Advaita Vedanta in addressing both timeless spiritual questions and contemporary challenges. The tradition proves remarkably capable of engaging with modern concerns—from neuroscience to artificial intelligence—while maintaining its essential insight into the non-dual nature of reality.

The key, as Swami repeatedly emphasizes, is that Vedanta isn't merely a philosophical system but a practical means of dehypnotization—of awakening from the dream of separation to recognize the consciousness that we already are. Whether through negation, devotion, selfless action, or study, the goal remains the same: to realize the truth that, in the words of the Upanishads, is "the light of lights, forever beyond darkness."

As the session closes with the traditional "Om shanti, shanti, shanti," the resonance of these ancient teachings continues to illuminate the questions of modern seekers, bridging centuries of wisdom with the pressing inquiries of our time.
